revision.text:
{{Infobox_President|name=İsa Yunis oğlu Qəmbər | nationality=Azerbaijani | smallimage= | order=Acting [[President of Azerbaijan]] | term_start=May 19, 1992 | term_end=June 16, 1992 | predecessor=[[Ayaz Mutallibov]] | successor=[[Abulfaz Elchibey]] | order2=[[Speaker of the National Assembly of Azerbaijan]] | term_start2=May 18, 1992 | term_end2=June 13, 1993 | predecessor2=[[Yagub Mammadov]] | successor2=[[Heydar Aliyev]] | birth_date={{Birth date and age|1957|2|24|mf=y}} | birth_place=[[Baku]], [[Azerbaijani Soviet Socialist Republic|Azerbaijan SSR]] | death_date= | death_place= | spouse=Aida Bağırova | party=[[Müsavat]] | vicepresident= | signature=Isa Gambar - signature.png }} '''Isa Yunis oglu Qambar''' ({{lang-az| İsa Yunis oğlu Qəmbər}}), also known as '''Isa Gambar''' or '''Isa Qambar''' (born February 24, 1957), is an [[Azerbaijan]]i politician and leader of [[Equality Party (Azerbaijan)|Equality Party]] ''(Müsavat)'', the largest opposition block in Azerbaijan. ==Biography details== {{Prose|date=April 2010}} {|border="0" | 1974 || Finished [[Baku]] High School No. 62 |- | 1979 || Graduated from the Faculty of History, [[Baku State University]] (BSU) |- | 1979–1982 || Worked at the [[Nakhichevan]] Research Center |- | 1982–1990 || Azerbaijan's Academy of Sciences Researched at the Institute of Oriental Studies |- | 1989–1991 || Academy of Sciences and one of the founders and leaders of the Popular Front of Azerbaijan (PFA) |- | 1990–1991 || Deputy Chairman of PFA |- | 1990 || Member of Parliament (MP) |- | 1991–1992 || Chairman of the Parliamentary Commission on Foreign Relations. |- | 1992 || Elected Baskan (Chairman) by the Congress of Restoration Committee of [[Equality Party (Azerbaijan)|Musavat]]. |- | May 1992 || Elected Parliamentary Speaker |- | June 16, 1992 || Acting [[President]] of the Azerbaijan Republic. Prepared the country for democratic election |- | June 13, 1993 || Resigned after overthrow of democratically elected president of [[Azerbaijan]] |- | July 16, 1993 || Arrested by the rebel forces that seized the power led by Heydar Aliyev |- | 1999, 2001–2003 || Co-Founder and Chairman of the Democratic Congress that included Azerbaijan's leading political parties |- | 2000 || Awarded the prize "A Friend of Journalists" |- | 2003 || Single presidential candidate for the opposition electoral bloc “[[Bizim Azərbaycan]]” (“Our Azerbaijan”) that associated more than 30 parties. |} İsa Qambar is married and has two sons. His wife, Aida Bağırova, is a Doctor of History, a Professor at Baku State University. ==2003 elections== [[Human Rights Watch]] commented on the 2003 elections:
Human Rights Watch research found that the government had heavily intervened in the elections campaign in favour of [[Prime Minister]] [[İlham Aliyev]], son of the current President [[Heydar Aliyev]]. The government had stacked the Central Election Commission and local election commission with its supporters, and banned local non-governmental organizations from monitoring the vote. As the elections drew nearer, government officials have openly sided with the campaign of İlham Aliyev, constantly obstructing opposition rallies and attempting to limit public participation in opposition events. In some cases, local officials have closed all the roads into town during opposition rallies, or have extended working and school hours, in one case, even declaring a Sunday work day, to prevent participation in opposition rallies. (source: http://www.hrw.org/backgrounder/eca/azerbaijan/index.htm)
==2011 protests== {{main|2011 Azerbaijani protests}} In his role as leader of Müsavat, Gambar has played a major part in spring 2011 demonstrations inspired by other [[Arab Spring|protests]] throughout the [[Middle East]]. He and his party have organized protests, occasionally joining with fellow opposition groups like the [[Azerbaijani Popular Front Party|Popular Front Party]] to rally in [[Baku]] despite a government ban and the steadfast efforts of security forces to disperse gatherings and arrest activists. "There is a criminal, authoritarian and corrupt regime in Azerbaijan, and the people of Azerbaijan no longer want to live under these conditions," Gambar told ''[[The New York Times]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/05/world/asia/05azerbaijan.html|agency=The New York Times|first=Michael|last=Schwirtz|title=Opposition in Azerbaijan Vows to Step Up Protests|date=4 April 2011|accessdate=25 April 2011}} In early April, Ilkin Gambar, the opposition leader's son currently serving in the [[Azerbaijani Army]], claimed on his [[Facebook]] page that he was being sent to the front lines in Azerbaijan's standoff with [[Armenia]] and that his father had been "warned" that this could be a result of his continuing involvement in protests. For his part, Isa Gambar said, "The Ministry of Defence has a right to place soldiers in any location at its disposal. So I don't want to politicize this issue."{{cite news|url=http://whatwaswritten.wordpress.com/2011/04/04/ilkin-gambar-sent-to-the-front-line-in-connection-to-protests/|agency=WhatWasWritten|title=Ilkin Gambar sent to the front line – in connection to protests?|first=Leyla|last=Najafli|date=4 April 2011|accessdate=25 April 2011}} ==See also== * [[President of Azerbaijan]] * [[Politics of Azerbaijan]] * [[National Assembly of Azerbaijan]] * [[Foreign relations of Azerbaijan]] * [[List of political parties in Azerbaijan]] ==References== *Forrest, Brett (Nov. 28, 2005). "Over A Barrel in Baku". ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'', pp. 54–60. ==External links== *The [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]]'s final report (source: [http://www.osce.org/documents/html/pdftohtml/1151_en.pdf.html HTML format] or [http://www.osce.org/documents/odihr/2003/11/1151_en.pdf PDF format])) *[http://www.isagambar.az/index-en.html İsa Qəmbər personal web-site with additional information about recent events] *[http://www.axisglobe.com/article.asp?article=468 Opposition Leader in the Interview to AIA: "Iran tries to influence the situation in Azerbaijan"] *[http://www.axisglobe.com/article.asp?article=375 The Azerbaijani Elections: İsa Qəmbər — Leader of the Largest Opposition Bloc] {{Start box}} {{s-off}} {{Succession box| title=[[President of Azerbaijan]]| before=[[Ayaz Mütallibov]]| years=May 19, 1992–June 16, 1992| after=[[Abulfaz Elchibey]] }} {{End box}} {{AzerbaijanPresidents}} {{Persondata | NAME =Gambar, Isa | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH =February 24, 1957 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijani Soviet Socialist Republic|Azerbaijan SSR]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gambar, Isa}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Chairmen of the National Assembly of Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Presidents of Azerbaijan]] [[Category:People from Baku]] [[Category:Azerbaijani democracy activists]] [[Category:Musavat politicians]] [[Category:Azerbaijani diplomats]] {{Arab Spring}} {{Azerbaijan-politician-stub}} {{Azerbaijan-bio-stub}} [[az:İsa Qəmbər]] [[de:İsa Qəmbər]] [[et:İsa Qəmbər]] [[eo:Isa Gambar]] [[fr:Issa Gambar]] [[ko:이사 감바르]] [[it:İsa Qember]] [[oc:Issa Gambar]] [[ru:Гамбар, Иса Юнис оглы]] [[tr:İsa Kamber]] [[uk:Іса Гамбар]]
